Nonie is married with four children.  Nonie is 42 years old and lives in Tacloban, Siquijor, Philippines.

To earn a living, Nonie has a backyard piggery and has had this type of business for two years. She earns approximately PHP 8,000 every two months. She has requested a loan of 15,000 PHP to purchase medicine and feed for raising pigs.

Nonie has been a member of Paglaum Multi Purpose Cooperative for 11 months.  In the future, Nonie hopes to finish her children's education (they are now studying in college) and gain more income from her business.

loans.use: To purchase medicine and feed for pigs

loans.name: Magu Group

texts.en:
Riziki, who is in her mid-30s, is single with four children. Two of her children do not go to school because she has no school fees but the two younger ones go to primary schools.  She also takes care of her mother.  She has had a food vendor business for five years now. She works from 12 noon to 4:00 p.m (only for four hours) and is able to make a fair monthly profit. 

This will be her third loan from Tujijenge, Tanzania. She used the previous loans to buy more food stock. As a single mother, she has to take care of her children and has paid back all her loans successfully. She wants a loan to buy 25 kilos of rice, 30 kilos of wheat flour, 1 backet of cooking oil and a sack of charcoal. Her dream is to be able to build her own house one day.

She will share this loan with her loan group "Magu", which has a total of 15 members who will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy rice, wheat flour, cooking oil and charcoal.

loans.name: Benita

texts.en: Benita, a 48-year-old resident of South Poblacion, Larena, Siquijor, is married and has two children. To earn a living, Benita has a business selling snacks in front of State College/school, earning about PHP 12,000.00.  A member of Paglaum Multi Purpose Cooperative for six months, she is requesting a loan of 10,000 to purchase ingredients for her business. In the future, Benita hopes to have savings for her children's tuition fees.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her snack-vending business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more potatoes, wheat flour, cooking oil and charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Ambrose

texts.en: Ambrose is married to Lilian and and they have three school-going children.  He joined Kiva field partner KADET after being referred by other borrowers and is servicing his first loan.  He has been construction material supply business for six years and makes  a monthly income of about 34,000 Kenyan shillings (KES). Ambrose plans to use this loan of 20,000 KES to buy more construction supplies such as bricks, cement, wood, sewage pipes, and gravel.

loans.use: to purchase construction supplies such as bricks, cement, wood, sewage pipes, and gravel.

loans.name: Kabumwa B Group

texts.en:
Jezina is the facilitator for Kabumwa B Group in Chwele.  She and her fellow group members joined One Acre Fund in 2011. Jezina says that she joined One Acre Fund in order to have additional profit to send her children to school and to access hybrid seed and fertilizer.  She also mentions that she wanted to be able to learn more about agriculture through the program.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important farming inputs to distribute to Jezina and her group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. 

This season, Jezina says, she had a good harvest, yielding 9.5 bags on 1/2 acre of land.  She says that before joining the program, she harvested 1 bag on 1/2 acre.  With the profits from her harvest, she plans on investing in her children's education, buying livestock, and purchasing medications.

On the far left is Jezina's One Acre Fund Field officer!

loans.use: to source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season

loans.name: Kamwe A Group

texts.en:
Peter is the facilitator for Kamwe A group in Chwele.  He and his group members joined One Acre Fund in 2011. Peter has a family that include five children and his wife.  He joined One Acre Fund in order to be able to harvest more maize on his farm, to access hybrid fertilizer and seed, and to move out of poverty.   

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important farming inputs to distribute to Peter and his group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. 

This year Peter harvested 15 bags of maize on 3/4 acre of land with his One Acre Fund inputs. Peter says the harvest was very good, especially compared with the 5 bags of maize that he used to harvest from the same area.  

With profits from his harvest, Peter will buy livestock, save money for the plowing costs of the 2012 season, and help his disabled child to access special education.  

On the far left is Peter's Field Officer Josephine.  Peter is pictured holding a file folder.

loans.use: to source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season

loans.name: Samah

texts.en:
Samah is a 29 year old single female, owner of a Music CDs and DVD shop, in addition to computer accessories selling.
She opened this business in 2004 and is working hard to improve it with new technologies and variety of products. Through this variety, Samah attracts different customers with different music tastes, in addition to computer accessories and technologies.
Samah is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua, it is her fifth cycle as Al Majmoua borrower,in order to increase her Music Discs and tapes with new and oldies releases, in addition to new computer technologies achieved. All her previous loans helped a lot in improving her business, and they reflected positively in improving her social situation. She is a good standing borrower, ambitious and a hard worker, who tries her best to prove for others that women are capable of doing anything and struggle to succeed it.
Samah intends to expand her working place, to a wider one, and she might need to move to another place for this reason, but it may take a little time to achieve it.

loans.use: To increase her stocks of CDs and DVDs

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet is a single mother who owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are water and electricity bills. For the past three years, she has operated an M-pesa (mobile money transfer) franchise. Her potential customers are neighbors and town dwellers.

Juliet decided to join Kiva field partner Yehu to access loans with the hope of boosting her business. She plans to use this 80,000 Kenyan shilling loan to increase the money float she uses in the mobile money transfer business.  She dreams of expanding her business in the future.

loans.use: to increase the money float for a mobile money transfer business.

loans.name: Wangoro A Group

texts.en:
Agneta is the deputy facilitator for Wangoro Group.  She has six children at home, along with her husband.  Agneta and her fellow group members have been part of One Acre Fund since 2010.  Agneta says that her reasons for joining were to be able to grow enough to feed her family, to use the profits for school fees, and to learn good agriculutural and farm finance practices.  

In her most recent harvest, Agneta's farm yielded 10 bags of maize on 1/2 acre, a very good harvest by her measure.  Before joining One Acre Fund, Agneta said that she was only getting 3 bags of maize from her 1/2 acre of land.  

With the profits from her maize, Agneta will invest in her children's education, invest in livestock and save for emergencies.  Other group members say that they will invest in more diverse food crops in addition to continuing maize planting.

In 2012, Agneta's group will plant a total of 5 acres of land with One Acre Fund.  Each farmer will plant between 1/2 and 1 acre of land.   

In this picture, Agneta's Field Officer is on the far left, and the wife of Mark is standing in for him.

loans.use: To plant maize in the 2012 season

loans.name: Turumkan's Group

texts.en:
Turumkan is the leader of this group. She is 52 and married to a driver, whose monthly salary is 10,000 soms. Together they have raised two sons and a daughter. Their daughter is married and, together with her husband, she works in Moscow. Their oldest son is a taxi driver and their second son is a private entrepreneur.

Turumkan works as a teacher at school; she also owns a grocery store, where she works in the evening. The family also started a business renting wedding dresses. Turumkan applied for the loan because she needs to purchase more wedding dresses so as to increase the variety of dresses that they offer. In the future, Turumkan wants to see her sons get married.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase wedding dresses

loans.name: Navigator Group

texts.en:
Elizabeth, who is in her early 40s, is married with three children who go to school. She has had a charcoal business for one year now.  She works from 6:00 am to 8:00 pm daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be her first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania which she wants to use for buying more sacks of charcoal. Her dream is to one day be able to build her own house and send her children to good schools.

She will share this loan with her loan group "Navigator" which has a total of 15 members who will hold each accountable for paying back their loans.

loans.use: to buy more sacks of charcoal.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase extra construction supplies to sell.

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice has practiced farming for the last four years. She is 24 years old, and she and her husband Antony have one child.  

She was introduced to KADET by one of our field officers and this will be her third loan. Since she paid all of her previous loans well and on time, she has been loaned 50,000 KES. She plans to use the loan amount to buy seeds and fertilizer and pay for labor.

In the future, Eunice hopes to become one of the leading farmers in the Ndunyu Njeru area.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizer and pay for labor.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is 33 years old. She and her husband Alfred have three children. She has been operating her retail shop for the past eleven years, making a monthly profit of 15,000 KES. This is her fourth loan. She has been loaned 50,000 KES which she plans to use to purchase stock like cooking oil, sugar, flour, soaps, etc.

With her anticipated profit she plans to pay school fees for her children. In the near future she hopes to own a wholesale business.

loans.use: to purchase stock like cooking oil, sugar, flour, soaps, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase new home furniture.

loans.name: 3.7.58 Quảng Hưng Group

texts.en:
Ms. Cúc works in agriculture farming poultry and cattle. She is requesting a loan to purchase baby cattle to raise to sell in the future.

Cúc is 50 years old and married with three children. She is the leader of a 7-member group, the 3.7.58 Quảng Hưng solidarity group. She lives and works in Thanh Hoa City, a semi-urban area in Thanh Hoa province, with no dependents.

In 2010, Cúc joined Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) to improve her  business. Cúc has successfully repaid 3 loans from FPW.

Cúc has been involved in this business for more than 10 years. The main hardship that Cúc faces in her business is the lack of capital.

With her business profit, Cúc hopes for her business to do well, for her family to be healthy and happy, and to build a new house.

loans.use: to purchase baby cattle to raise to sell in future

loans.name: Cristine

texts.en:
Cristine is 28 years old and lives in North Poblacion, Larena, Siquijor. She is married with two children.

Cristine sells of ready-to-wear clothing to earn a living and has had this business for two years.  Each month, she earns 12,000 Philippine pesos (PHP)  doing this type of work. She has requested a loan for 10,000 PHP to purchase more stocks of clothing to sell.

Cristine has been a member of Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative for seven months. In the future, Cristine's dream is to have savings in preparation for her children's future education.

loans.use: To purchase more stocks of clothes to sell

loans.name: Dama

texts.en:
Dama is 40 years old and a married mother of 8 children. She is a dry-fish vendor. She has been in this business for the last 10 years. Dama has been a KADET client and has been loaned 20,000 KES in this, her fourth loan to finance her business. She plans to purchase more fish for resale.

With the anticipated profits, she will repay her loan and gradually expand her business. Her dream is to become a successful business lady.

loans.use: purchase more fish for resale

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
This is Victoria, 54, a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Leonardo, a maintenance worker, and a father to her 4 children. The oldest child is already working, one is in elementary school, and two are still staying at home. She, together with her husband and children, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, Victoria is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Victoria operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling them by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 300 PHP in sales every day.     

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a 13,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Victoria hopes her business grows into a mini-grocery and dreams of being able to give her children a good and high-quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business

loans.name: 5 Dong Ve Group

texts.en:
Hà is providing wine to pubs. She is applying for a loan to purchase materials to make wine to sell. Hà has been involved in this business for more than 10 years. One of the most critical business difficulties that concerns her is her lack of capital.

Hà is 41 years old and she is married with 2 children. She is the leader of a 4-member group, the 5 Dong Ve solidarity group. She lives with 2 dependents and works in T. Hoa city, a semi-urban area in T. Hoa province.

This is Hà's first loan with T. Hoa Fund of Poor Women.
 
With her business profit, Hà hopes for her business to do well, to remodel her house, and for her family to be healthy and happy.

loans.use: to purchase material to make wine to sell

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith is a married woman with 2 children, both of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and clothing.

For over 3 years Judith has operated a motorcycle transport business. Her potential customers are neighbors and town dwellers. In addition, she also operates a retail shop selling household products which contributes to her other source of income. Judith faces a major challenge of competition from other motorcycle operators. She dreams of having a wholesale shop in the future.

With the 80,000 KES loan, Judith wants to purchase bundles of maize flour, wheat flour, sugar, tea leaves and washing detergents. She decided to work with Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of maize flour, wheat flour, sugar, tea leaves and washing detergents

loans.name: Bilal

texts.en:
Bilal is a 37-year-old married man who has worked in vehicle repairs for 20 years. This long experience gave him a special position in his area. Customers come requesting his services from nearby villages because of his good quality of work. 

Bilal is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua, in order to buy new tools and updated machines necessary to improve his quality of work given. He is an Al Majmoua borrower for two successful cycles. His previous loan was invested in his business, and reflected positively on his social and financial situation. He is a borrower in good-standing, a man with special skills recommended by most of his customers. Bilal has worked hard to prove himself since he started with a very small capital and now he's proving successful.

In addition to repairing vehicles, Bilal buys used cars, does necessary maintenance for them, and sells them at a good price, so he's starting a new business which deals with selling used cars and hopes to support it as much as he can. 

Bilal is planning to expand into the car-selling sector and hopes he can achieve what's requested as soon as possible.

loans.use: to buy new tools and machines necessary for his business

loans.name: Namurunda Group

texts.en:
Beatrice is the facilitator for Namurunda Group in Chwele.  Beatrice has been a member of One Acre Fund since 2010.  At home, Beatrice is a mother of seven. She joined One Acre Fund in order to ensure food security for her family and to have income that allows her to pay school fees.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important farming inputs to distribute to Beatrice and her group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. 

This year, Beatrice harvested 8 bags of maize on 1/2 acre of land, a good harvest!  Before joining One Acre Fund, Beatrice was only able to harvest 2 bags from 1/2 acre.  Beatrice will use her maize income on livestock, home repairs, and education for her children.

In the picture, Beatrice is second from the left, holding a One Acre Fund maize seed information sheet.  On the far left is the One Acre Fund Field officer, Phyllis.

loans.use: to source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season

loans.name: Musharraf

texts.en:
Musharraf is a 44-year-old woman. She is married with three sons and two daughters. Musharraf has a project raising sheep and benefits from selling their products. This is the only source of income for the family. Musharraf wants to buy fodder to feed the sheep better in order to increase their productivity and sell more of their products to generate more income. Musharraf does not have enough money to pay, so she needs to take a loan of JOD 700 from FATEN.

When Musharraf takes the FATEN loan, which is repaid on a monthly basis, she can purchase sheep fodder and, therefore, increase the amount of sheep products she'll have to sell. Musharraf is photographed in the FATEN branch.

loans.use: To purchase fodder for the sheep she is raising.

loans.name: Jazgul's Group

texts.en:
Jazgul is the leader of this group. She is 27 years old and married; her husband works in Russia as a porter. Jazgul has two children, both of whom are preschool age (under seven). In order to earn money Jazgul wholesales dairy products. She started this activity five years ago and at the moment her monthly profit is 3,000 Kyrgyzstani Soms (KGS). She applied for this loan because she needs money to purchase hay for cattle to feed them during the winter season. In the future Jazgul wants to start repairing her house.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase hay for cattle.

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en:
Caroline is a married woman with five children, two of whom attend school while the other three are employed. She lives in her own house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her monthly expenses are school fees, clothing and food for her family.

Caroline has operated a business selling palm wine for the past seven years. She sells from home to her neighbors. She also operates a retail shop. Her major challenge is competition with other palm wine vendors. Her dream is to expand to a wholesale shop in the future.

With this loan of 40,000 Kenyan Shillings (KES) she wants to purchase jerrycans for storing palm wine for sale. Caroline decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase jerrycans for storing palm wine for sale.

loans.name: Lukas

texts.en:
Lukas is 29 years old, married to Ann, and not yet blessed with children. He offers transportation to the residents of Kiserian. He has been in this  business for the last five years and earns an income of 30,000 Kenyan Shillings (KES) per month.

He was introduced to KADET by a friend who is also a client of KADET. He has good credit history with KADET and is applying for his third loan of 50,000 KES. He plans to use the funds to repair his motor bike. He will use his anticipated profit to buy another motor bike.

Lukas hopes to own a Mini bus in the near future.

loans.use: To service his motor bike.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter has practiced farming in the town of Ndunyu Njeru for the last five years. He is 48 years old and married to Wanjiru. They have three school-going children.  

He was introduced to KADET by one of our field officers and this will be his first loan. He plans to use the loan amount to buy seeds and fertilizer.

In the future, Peter hopes to become one of the leading farmers in the Ndunyu Njeru area.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizer.
